feed.title: Louis Garénaux
feed.subtitle: Louis Garénaux is a researcher in mathematics. He is interested in long time stability for partial differential equations and in travelling wave solutions.

entry.title: Seminar in Clermont-Ferrand
entry.content:
Visiting Clermont-Ferrand for a couple of days in December, and giving a presentation in the Partial Differential Equations and Numerical Analysis seminar.

Title: Large time dynamics in Klein-Gordon equations

Abstract: The Klein-Gordon equation is a wave equation with an additional mass damping term. In this presentation, I will review some literature about the dynamic of such equation when settled on an unbounded one-dimensional spatial domain. I will further present some new results regarding the global existence and long time behaviour of solutions that are initialy close to constant or periodic equilibria. Most notably, I will talk about a viscous approximation of this equation, as well as describe how uniformly local orbital stability can be obtained from polar decomposition. This is joint work with Björn de Rijk and Emile Bukieda.

entry.title: Visiting Dalian
entry.content:
Visiting Xian Liao at Dalian University, China for two weeks in December 2025. I will be giving a minicourse “Orbital stability of propagated waves in parabolic systems” at the Dynamical System seminar and presentations at the Differential Equations seminar.

Presentation titles:

  • Stability of propagated fronts in scalar balance laws
  • Large time dynamics in Klein-Gordon equations

entry.title: Seminar in Karlsruhe
entry.content:
Visiting Karlsruhe for a couple of days, and giving a presentation in the Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations seminar.

Title: Orbital stability for monostable fronts in reaction-diffusion equations

Abstract: In this presentation, I will discuss the long-time asymptotic stability of a particular class of travelling waves. Monostable fronts are heteroclinic connections between linearly stable and linearly unstable constant equilibria. Until now, all known stability result assume additional localization of the initial perturbation. We will see how to remove this condition to show orbital stability with respect to phase shift.
